On the subject of Satan, Elaine Pagels, in The Origin of Satan, Random House Pub. treats in considerable detail the evolution of Satan within Judeo/Christian literature. For example, she notes that the Hebrew root stn translates to "one who opposes, obstructs, or acts as adversary", not necessarily a bad thing. Satan, then, was any one of the angels sent by God for the specific purpose of blocking or obstructing human activity. Thus, they were considered to be God's obedient servants. The book of Numbers, chap. 22, illustrates this: Balaam sets out on a journey and is confronted by an angel who proceeds to block Balaam's path...
 
 Nu 22:22 And God's anger was kindled because he went: and the angel of the LORD stood in the way for an adversary against him.
 
 Or consider the book of Job. The following is taken from the KJV. In the Jewish version, substitute "Adversary" for "Satan", who has now become a single individual...
 
 Job 1:6-8 Now there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan came also among them. And the LORD said unto Satan, Whence comest thou? Then Satan answered the LORD, and said, From going to and fro in the earth, and from walking up and down in it. And the LORD said unto Satan, Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God, and escheweth evil?
 
 Satan responds that Job has resaon to praise God given that God has been good to Job with regard to material blessings. God then allows Satan to test Job's faith by visiting misery upon him. Thus, God and Satan enter into a gentlemen's bet concerning Job. Satan is not yet a bad guy. That transformation comes about in later Jewish writings and, of course, in Christian writings.

 God then admonished Adam and Eve to not taste of the knowledge of 'good AND EVIL' because the knowledge of both halves of the complete cosmology would introduce death (and death producing machinations) into the exclusively good context. 
 So, death was first introduced by Adam and Eve's disregard (disobedience) of God's counsel.

It is my understanding that much of the Old Testament states (interpreted) that Good and Evil are the two faces of God. Kind of like a parent telling a child, "Don't make me have to kick your behind".
Yes, I am aware of that interpretation, however there are others and since that one has to stick something in (the two faces of God) to explain the creation of evil, I am not really satisfied with it. Another interpretation explains it this way (simplistically, granted):
 All God created is good.
 Man cannot understand creation as God does.
 Man ate from the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil and "his eyes were opened". He saw and divided creation (in his own mind) into two powers: the power of good and the power of evil - when there is only power: the power of good. Man took onto himself the mantle of a judge and judgment is God's alone. Man cannot understand the trajectory of creation but deludes himself into thinking he can. A consequence of believing in two powers is being thrown out of the Garden of Eden. This interpretation connects much more clearly with the later teachings of Jesus: "Judge not lest you be judged." "Unless you be like a child you cannot enter the Kingdom of Heaven." And most clearly, "Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you;" Then he tells us why: "That ye may be the children of your Father which is in heaven: for he maketh his sun to rise on the evil and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust." God does not divide his creation into two camps; he sends the rain and sun onto all his creation which is good. He is encouraging us to "Be perfect like your Father in Heaven."
 
 To me it is a most fascinating and uplifting inderstanding.
